questionListItems.title:
My son learns better with hardcopy notes, how can he go about printing
hardcopy notes in school?

answer.body:
Students who would like hardcopy notes will liaise with subject representatives. The subject
representative will initiate the printing process.

questionListItems.title: Will the school conduct talks on the harmful consequences of device addiction ?

answer.body:
There are scheduled cyber wellness lessons for our students and timely reminders weekly to
challenge our students to play outdoors and to limit their screen time.

questionListItems.title: My son has CCA, where does he lock his PLD after school?

answer.body:
The school has installed lockers for students to lock their devices when away from their
classrooms. Students need to obtain a locker key from the librarian, sign for the duration of
use and return the key to the librarian before they leave school at the end of the day. The
school does not encourage students to leave their PLDs in school. They are expected to
bring home the devices at the end of the school day so that they can utilise them for
assignments and learning at home

questionListItems.title:
For DMA settings, can we know what's the default setting during and after
school hours if we choose the default option.

answer.body:
The default DMA‚Äôs school setting is from 6:30am to 6:30pm for school profile with a sleep

profile set from 11pm to 6:00am. The After-School Profile has three options, namely:

  • Default where the After-School DMA profile follows the school default profile.

  • Option A where the After-School DMA profile can be modified by the parents.

  • Option B where the DMA profile is disabled after school hours.


Gudes to each of the DMA option can be found here

(Default) DMA Parent Guide.pdf

(Option A) DMA Parent Guide.pdf

(Option B) DMA Parent Guide.pdf


Parents can request to change the DMA option after the start of each term through this form

go.gov.sg/chssecdma. However, changes to the DMA (After-School) profile will only take

effect at the end of each term.

questionListItems.title: What is covered by the warranty and insurance?

answer.body:
The PLD will come with a 3-year warranty and insurance coverage allowing for claims of two

repairs or one replacement. The following events are covered by insurance:

  • Fire

  • Lightning

  • Power Surges

  • Accidental e.g water spillage, drop etc

  • Theft due to forcible entry

  • Robbery

questionListItems.title:
What happens if the device is stolen / lost and will the replacement be of the
same or a different model?

answer.body:
The insurance coverage is only applicable to situations of damages and loss where the
student has taken all necessary precautions to safeguard the PLD. A police report will need
to be made for the insurance claim.
The device replacement will only be of the same model as the insurance covers the model
'Lenovo 500e Gen3' for 2023 level 1 and 'Lenovo 500e Gen2‚Äô for 2023 level 2 to 4 and not
the category of chromebooks.

questionListItems.title: What is the support given if a student encounters technical problems?

answer.body:
There will be In-class Cyber Innovation Ambassadors who will be briefed on troubleshooting
common ICT issues. More complex issues will be referred to the in-house service desk at
the Media Resource Room which is manned daily by Desktop Engineers for students from
8am-4pm. Further issues can be referred to Lenovo Service Centre at 3 Irving Road, #01-17
Tai Seng Centre, Singapore 369522.

questionListItems.title: Is there any financial subsidy for purchasing the device?

answer.body:
Financial subsidies are available to students whose household income is less than $4,000.
However, students who are already on MOE financial assistance schemes do not need to
apply as the PLD will be automatically subsidised. Please approach the school's General
Office for more information on subsidies.

questionListItems.title:
How can I apply for a subsidy for the purchase of a laptop for NDLP as my GHI is
less than $4000 and my child is currently not under MOE or school FAS?

answer.body:
You may ask your son to collect the application forms for subsidy from the General Office.
Complete the application form with supporting documents. Return the form to the General
Office within the specified timeline.

questionListItems.title: How many online submissions can I make?

answer.body:
You can only perform one online submission. Please think carefully before you select and
submit your subject combination options.

questionListItems.title: What subject combination will I be allocated if I did not get the combination I opted for?

answer.body:
As the allocation of subject combination is criteria-based, students who are not allocated what
they opted for, will be allocated the next combination automatically. Students will be able to
submit an Appeal Form to the General Office during the appeal period to change their
combination, if need be.

questionListItems.title:
As I am only interested in doing SC3 (e.g. Triple Science and 1 Humanity), why do I need to
indicate a second Humanity subject during the submission process?

answer.body:
All students will need to indicate a second Humanity subject. In the event they are not
allocated SC3, they will be allocated the next combination (e.g. Double Science)
automatically, in which they are required to do two Humanities.

questionListItems.title:
How do I find out the results of the allocation of subject combination and appeal (if
applicable)?

answer.body:
Students will be informed of all results via SLS (All Ears). Please check results and do not
assume you will be allocated your first choice.
All results will also be displayed on the notice board located outside the HOD Room.

questionListItems.title:
Will I be placed in the same class in Level 3 as my friends, if we are allocated the same
subject combination?

answer.body: You may or may not be placed in the same class as your friends in Level 3.

questionListItems.title: Should I choose to do an 8-subject or 9-subject combination?

answer.body:
Students are advised to take into consideration their total curriculum workload in Level 3.
This includes their commitment and workload in external academic (e.g. third language) and
non-academic areas (e.g. CCA, SLB).
All IP students must do a minimum of 8 subjects.
